Location: Gilt Dragon Shipwreck Site, Ledge Point, Western Australia
Recommended Reason: 1656 Dutch East India Company ship with 8 chests of silver coins worth 78,600 guilders, partially recovered but more remains
Supporting Evidence: Historical records confirm 8 chests of silver coins, partial recovery in 1960s-1970s, ongoing archaeological interest

Location: Batavia Shipwreck, Houtman Abrolhos Islands, Western Australia
Recommended Reason: 1629 Dutch VOC vessel with silver coins and trade goods, site of Australia's first documented mass murder, ongoing archaeological significance
Supporting Evidence: Wreck discovered with silver coins and artifacts, extensive archaeological documentation, UNESCO consideration

Location: Tryall Shipwreck, Monte Bello Islands, Western Australia
Recommended Reason: 1622 English East Indies vessel carrying 500 silver reales and gold spangles for King of Siam, first known shipwreck in Australian waters
Supporting Evidence: Historical records document silver coins and gold spangles cargo, earliest recorded treasure loss in Western Australia

Location: Dampier Archipelago Pearling Camps, Western Australia
Recommended Reason: Historic pearling industry sites with evidence of valuable pearl collections and trade artifacts from 19th-20th centuries
Supporting Evidence: Archaeological surveys found bottles, coins, and evidence of pearling operations, multiple graves and camps documented

Recommended Reason: Ghost town from pearling era with documented coin finds including 17 coins from 1791-1912 and silver artifacts
Supporting Evidence: Personal accounts of multiple coin discoveries including Dutch, English, Chinese and French coins, plus silver Japanese snuff box

Location: Witwatersrand Gold Fields, New South Wales
Recommended Reason: Historic gold rush area with potential caches from early prospectors and hidden deposits from 1850s-1860s gold boom
Supporting Evidence: Well-documented gold rush history, numerous documented finds of gold nuggets and caches in the region

Recommended Reason: Historic shipping lane with multiple shipwrecks, Spanish coins and artifacts reported by Trepang fishermen and pearlers
Supporting Evidence: Historical accounts of Spanish gold and silver coins, guns, swords sold by local fishermen to ship passengers

Location: Endeavour Cannon Site, Six Mile Reef, Queensland
Recommended Reason: Cannons jettisoned by Captain Cook's Endeavour in 1770, discovered in 1968 under coral growth, archaeological significance
Supporting Evidence: Cannons discovered by Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia team in 1968, confirmed Cook's Endeavour artifacts

Recommended Reason: 1966 discovery of gold coins, gold scarabs and Egyptian calendar stone estimated from 2,780 BC, suggesting pre-European contact
Supporting Evidence: Reported discovery of gold artifacts and Egyptian calendar stone, though origin disputed by mainstream archaeology

Location: Phoenician Bronze Plate Site, North-West Western Australia
Recommended Reason: Bronze plate found near silver deposits, identified by US university as Phoenician origin 200-700 BC, suggests ancient contact
Supporting Evidence: Bronze plate analyzed by US university and identified as Phoenician, found near galena ore deposits indicating silver mining
